ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Concrete knowledge of many neuroscience methods
Brain imaging techniques, experimental design, overall physiological signals that come from the brain and how we can measure them
This is a very in depth and informative course about the different techniques of looking at the brain in terms of structure, function and connectivity. It is hard but very interesting.
I only learned new things in this class. Many skills about the field and its real life applications, as well as relevant developments.
Thorough knowledge and theoretical application of neuroscience methods. system level + practical

I learned, from a super basic level all the way up to practical considerations, how many different brain imaging methods work. This includes foundational physics, statistics, experimental design, and relevant biological features that make imaging possible.
A working understanding of common/new brain imaging and measuring techniques and what they are used for.
Learned about various brain imaging techniques.
research methods in neuroscience, such as EEG, MEG, TMS, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor McCarthy is really great, he's a very clear lecturer who really takes the time to make sure we understand everything even when things are technical, it's not too much work week-to-week and the content is interesting
Weaknesses: there's just a lot of content and it can be dense but that's kind of inevitable with the topic
Strengths is that it is very interesting and well organized.
I like this class a lot. I am very content with how it was conducted.
Cannot think of any weaknesses. Well explained and covered all the necessary material.
This course was incredible. I'm not really sure how it could be improved.

Strengths: Interesting lectures, it is very nice that they are recorded and posted. Review sessions were very helpful. The homework was doable and helpful for understanding the material. Ed discussion is good too.
Great professor who really cares about his students
more points awarded toward homework questions; more homework questions instead of a heavy emphasis on the two midterms and final being the grade determiner.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!!! Professor McCarthy is an incredible professor and this is such valuable knowledge to have for anyone hoping to do neuroscience research.

I would recommend it to another student who is a psych/neuro/cog sci major, the material is very interesting and very relevant to work in all these fields. Even though the material can be conceptually hard the class itself is very fair and is set up for you to learn the material and do well.

Definitely if you are neuroscience r if you need a research methods class. If you are psych major and need research methods I wouldn't really recommend but if you are intereste then take it! - there's not too much neuro bacjground require.
Absolutely.
Yes, if you're prepared to dedicate real time to learning the concepts. All the materials, resources, and professor are there to help you but you must take it upon yourself to dedicate the time.
Yes! Super practical if youre heading into research/clinical work and want to understand these techniques.
Only if they need it for their major or if they plan on pursuing med school or neuroscience research. Professor McCarthy is great, but the content was dense and exams relied heavily on memorization.
Yes!  Professor McCarthy is a great lecturer
